segments.en: Linked Discourses 7
2. Lay Followers
18. Collecting Firewood

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa sambahulā antevāsikā kaṭṭhahārakā māṇavakā yena vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā addasaṃsu bhagavantaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā. Disvāna yena bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhāradvājagottaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several youths, students of one of the Bhāradvāja brahmins, approached a forest grove while collecting firewood. They saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, with his body straight, and mindfulness established right there. Seeing this, they went up to Bhāradvāja and said to him,
“Please sir, you should know this.

segments.pli: Asukasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe samaṇo nisinno pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”.
segments.en: In such and such a forest grove the ascetic Gotama is sitting down cross-legged, with his body straight, and mindfulness established right there.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ yena so vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then Bhāradvāja together with those students went to that forest grove

segments.pli: Addasā kho bhagavantaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
segments.en: where he saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged, with his body straight, and mindfulness established right there.

segments.pli: Disvāna yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: He went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:
“Deep in the jungle so full of terrors,
you’ve plunged into the empty, desolate wilderness.
Still, steady, and graceful:
how beautifully you meditate, mendicant!

segments.pli: Na yattha gītaṃ napi yattha vāditaṃ,
segments.en: Where there is no song or music,
a lonely sage resorts to the wilderness.
This strikes me as an amazing thing,
that you dwell so joyfully alone in the jungle.
I suppose you wish to be reborn in the company
of the supreme sovereign of the heaven of the Three and Thirty.
Is that why you resort to the desolate wilderness,
to practice austerities for attaining Brahmā?”
“Any wishes and hopes that are always attached
to the many and various realms—
the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—
I’ve eliminated them all down to the root.
So I’m wishless, unattached, disengaged;
amongst all things, my vision is clear.
I’ve attained the state of grace, the supreme awakening;
I meditate alone, brahmin, and self-assured.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama … pe …
segments.en: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! …
From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying in the…

suttaplex.blurb: Some brahmin students are collecting firewood when they see the Buddha in meditation. They return and inform their teacher, who visits the Buddha to ask him how he is so peaceful in the wild forest.
